(b) Pre-Approved Plans Program
) Purpose: This IRM provides procedures and guidance to employees who process and review Opinion Letter applications from Pre-Approved Plan and Providers and Mass Submitters. (

) Audience: a. Pre-Approved Plans Program clerk (clerk) b. First and Second-Level Reviewers who work Pre-Approved Plans c. Pre-Approved Plans Coordinators (Coordinators) d. Pre-Approved Plans Program manager (
) Policy Owner: Director, EP (
) Program Owner: EP (

) Program Goals: The goal of EP Determinations is to ensure that plans with the tax laws. We do this by reviewing applications for Determination Opinion Letters and protecting the public interest by applying the tax law integrity and fairness to all. (

amendment cycle (Cycle 2) and provides rules for determining when remedial amendment periods expire. It also modiﬁes the procedures for the IRC 403(b) Pre-Approved Program to be similar to procedures cable to the IRC 401(a) Pre-Approved Program. The submission period for the second pre-approved 403(b) plan cycle begins May 2, 2022, and ends on May 1, 2023.

The following table lists several deﬁnitions used in this IRM:

Term Deﬁnition Adoption Agreement The part of the plan that lists the options an adopting employer may select. Basic Plan Document The part of a plan containing all the non-elective provisions applicable to all adopting employers. The basic plan document may not have any options. Eligible Employer An employer described in IRC 403(b)(1)(A). Identical Adopter Any person with an established place of business in the U.S. that is accessible during every business day who sponsors a plan as a word-for-word identical adopter of a Mass Submitter, regardless of the number of employers expected to adopt the plan.

) has an established place of business in the United States where it is accessible during every business day, and, (
) submits Opinion Letter applications on behalf of at least

Employee Plans Determination Letter Program
Deﬁnition For IRC
(a) plans, any person (including, if applicable, a Mass Submitter) that, (
) has an established place of business in the United States where it is accessible during every business day, and, (
) represents to the IRS in its appli- cation for an Opinion Letter that it has at least

employer- clients, each of which is reasonably expected to adopt the same Pre-Approved Plan of the Provider. A Provider may request an Opinion Letter for more than one plan provided it represents to the IRS that it has at least
employer-clients in the aggregate, each of which is reasonably expected to adopt at least one of the Provider’s plans. For IRC
(b) plans, any person (including, if applicable, a Mass Submitter) that (
) has an established place of business in the United States where it is accessible during every business day, and (
) represents to the IRS in its application for an Opinion Letter that it has at least

Eligible Employers, each of which is reasonably expected to adopt one of the Pre-Approved Plans of the Provider. Not withstand- ing the preceding sentence, a person that is otherwise eligible to be a Provider generally may apply for an Opinion Letter for a plan that is intended to be a Retirement Income Account without satisfying the
-Eligible Employer requirement with respect to that plan. However, if that person also applies for an Opinion Letter with respect to a IRC
(b) Pre-approved Plan that is not a Retirement Income Account, the person would need to meet the
-Eligible-Employer requirement for the plan that is not a Retirement Income Account. Cycle Rev. Proc.

401(a) and 403(b) Pre-Approved Plans Program 7.11.4
Deﬁnition The separate portion of an IRC

(a) plan that contains the trust agreement or custodial account agreement and includes provisions covering matters such as the powers and duties of trustees, investment authority and the kinds of investments that the plan sponsor may make. Note: The trust agreement or custodial account agreement must be in a document separate from the rest of the plan. Copies of trusts or other funding mediums must not be submitted. The IRS will not review for, and the Opinion Letter will not cover, any provisions included in trust documents.

The trust agreement or custodial account agreement must be in a document separate from the rest of the plan. Copies of trusts or other funding mediums must not be submitted. The IRS will not review for, and the Opinion Letter will not cover, any provisions included in trust documents.

The thumb or ﬂash drive provided by the taxpayer shall be handled with the minimum security set out in IRM

) Pre-Approved Providers or Mass Submitters with valid opinion/advisory from the immediately preceding cycle are expected to submit applications each RAC on time. The same is true for a new Provider or Mass Submitter unless they didn’t exist during the general deadline to ﬁle. (
) If Providers or Mass Submitters don’t submit by the scheduled due date, it could result in a delay in processing the application and issuing a favorable letter. (
) An employer adopting a late-submitted Pre-Approved Plan could have less than the normal two-year adoption period. See Rev. Proc.

) The IRS: a. Issues virtually all Opinion Letters at the same time for Pre-Approved Opinion Providers and Mass Submitters who ﬁle their plans timely. b. Publishes a uniform
-year timeframe in an announcement during adopting employers must adopt the newly approved plans. (

, Assumption of Sponsor- the Issuance ship or IRM

), Late Submissions, they should submit user fees Letters in a cashier’s check or certiﬁed check made payable to the United States Treasury. Paying the user fee with a business or personal check will delay IRS issuing the letter by approximately four to six weeks. (
) A minor-modiﬁer is a plan that only has minor changes to an otherwise identical word-for-word Mass Submitter’s Pre-Approved Plan. These plans don’t require an in-depth technical review. (
) For minor-modiﬁer plans: The Mass Submitter submits the Form
-B for
(a) plans or the appropriate application form (Form
-C or the A from either the Rev. Proc.
or Rev.Proc.
) for
(b) plans. When the Mass Submitter plan receives its preliminary notiﬁcation (see IRM
, Preliminary Notiﬁcations), they prepare a plan document for each minor-modiﬁer application and submit them to the IRS. For IRC
(a) plans, the Mass Submitter follows the directions in Rev. Proc.
, Section
). For IRC
(b) plans, the Mass Submitter follows the directions in Rev. Proc.

) Minor-modiﬁer applications are generally assigned to the ﬁrst-level reviewer, who reviewed the Mass Submitter lead plan. (

) The ﬁrst-level reviewer only reviews the changes that differ from the lead If the reviewer determines the changes aren’t minor, he/she stops reviewing and offers the applicant the opportunity to ﬁle as a Provider (i.e., non-mass submitter). (
) Typically, the minor-modiﬁers don’t go through the second or discretionary ordinator review process. (
) The Pre-Approved Plans Program clerk helps manage the case ﬂow. (
) Clerk duties include: Plans a. Establishing inventory records. b. Transmitting the user fee. c. Creating an electronic case ﬁle. d. Updating case status. (

) As soon as you receive the application, create a record of it on the TE/GE Rulings and Agreements Control System (TRAC). Enter the following the Record tion into the system: a. Provider or Mass Submitter name and address. b. Employer Identiﬁcation Number (EIN). (
) Internal Revenue Manual

(b) Pre-Approved Plans Program
) The case is now ready for assignment to a ﬁrst-level reviewer. (

) Place each paper Opinion Letter submission in its own folder and keep in Pre-Approved Plans Program storage room until determined to be Keep ﬂash or thumb drives in the folder with the paper documents. (

) After cases are added to TRAC, print and mail acknowledgement letters to Providers and Mass Submitters to notify them that we received their initial mission. The acknowledgment letters may be printed either on a singular or in a bulk run based on the input date in the TRAC system. (
) Update the status code of the TRAC record for the assignment/transfer of Approved Plan cases to reviewers and/or Coordinators when necessary. (

) When the Coordinators notify the clerk that a case is being assigned to a level reviewer, the ﬁrst-level reviewer should access the assigned case ﬁle in the designated shared folder, the clerk will update the case in TRAC indicating the ﬁrst-level reviewer’s TRAC I.D. number and the level review” status code. Then email the Coordinators and the ﬁrst-level reviewer letting them know you updated TRAC. (
) When a ﬁrst-level reviewer emails you that a case is ready for second-level assignment, update the case record in TRAC to the “awaiting assignment second-level review” status code. (

) When the Coordinators notify you that a case is being assigned to a level reviewer and that the reviewer should access the assigned electronic case ﬁle in the designated shared folder, update the case record in TRAC cating the second-level reviewer’s TRAC I.D. number and the “assigned to second-level reviewer” status code. Then email the Coordinators and the second-level reviewer letting them know you updated TRAC. (

) Once an electronic case ﬁle is assigned to both a ﬁrst-level reviewer and a second-level reviewer, it isn’t returned to the Coordinators until complete. Whenever the two reviewers need to exchange the electronic case, they should notify the clerk in an email. (
) Update the case record on TRAC to reﬂect the change in the current er’s TRAC I.D. number and indicate ﬁrst or second-level review status. (
) After both reviewers complete their reviews, the second-level reviewer the clerk indicating the case is ready for discretionary ﬁnal review and of issuance of the Opinion Letter. (
) Once the Coordinators receive each reviewer’s ﬁnal Form

, Case nology Record (CCR) electronically, one of the Coordinators emails the the total case hours (ﬁrst and second-level reviewer) to input into TRAC. Update the case on TRAC to show the case is in discretionary ﬁnal review status and put it in the Coordinator’s TRAC I.D. number.

and

cialists perform ﬁrst or second-level review at the direction of the Pre- Approved Plans Program manager. (
) To ensure consistency, all of a Provider’s or Mass Submitter’s lead plans are assigned to one reviewer. (
) The ﬁrst and second-level reviewers email the Coordinators and their group manager when they need work. The Coordinators assign all work (

) First-Level Reviewer: When the Coordinators notify you of a case access the electronic case ﬁle in the designated shared folder. Complete the following as part of your initial review: a. Update the time sheet (We
TS) and the Pre-Approved Plans monthly report. (See IRM

, Monthly Report.) b. Prepare an electronic case assignment letter (see the Pre-Approved folder on the shared server for a template) and send (fax, mail, or it to the Provider or Mass Submitter. Include your name and contact mation on the letter. Complete an electronic Form
, Case Chronology Record (CCR). Complete one Form

for each case ﬁle. Include your name on the form and enter assigned for the ﬁrst-level review as the ﬁrst entry under the section Topics Discussed, Informa- tion Requested or Other Action Taken. If more than one page, each page accordingly, or include the year in the ﬁrst date entry of each page. Don’t upload the CCR to the electronic case ﬁle stored in the ignated shared folder. c. Complete your review using the applicable Cumulative List and Listing Required Modiﬁcations (LRMs). Your review must include: Form
series application or application form contained in the Appendix A to Proc.
for

(b) plans, the cover letter, any plan documents, adoption agreements. Complete the applicable Alert Guidelines when the plan doesn’t follow the LRM. d. When you complete all case ﬁles for a Provider or Mass Submitter, prepare an electronic draft Letter
to request any additional tion. Explain each change request or comment and cite the appropriate legal authority.
Generally, only grade
and
EP specialists from EP Determinations are selected. All lead plans go through a ﬁrst-level of review with a specialist and then a second-level of review with another specialist. All grade
specialists work as ﬁrst-level reviewers and all grade
spe- cialists perform ﬁrst or second-level review at the direction of the Pre- Approved Plans Program manager.
The ﬁrst and second-level reviewers email the Coordinators and their group manager when they need work. The Coordinators assign all work electronically.
7.11.4.4.1 (09-08-2022) First-Level Review Process
following as part of your initial review: a. Update the time sheet (We
TS) and the Pre-Approved Plans monthly report. (See IRM

, Monthly Report.) b. Prepare an electronic case assignment letter (see the Pre-Approved folder on the shared server for a template) and send (fax, mail, or email) it to the Provider or Mass Submitter. Include your name and contact mation on the letter. Complete an electronic Form
, Case Chronology Record (CCR). Complete one Form

for each case ﬁle. Include your name on the form and enter assigned for the ﬁrst-level review as the ﬁrst entry under the section Topics Discussed, Informa- tion Requested or Other Action Taken. If more than one page, number each page accordingly, or include the year in the ﬁrst date entry of each page. Don’t upload the CCR to the electronic case ﬁle stored in the des- ignated shared folder. c. Complete your review using the applicable Cumulative List and Listing of Required Modiﬁcations (LRMs). series application or application form contained in the Appendix A to Rev. Proc.
for

) The Coordinators’ duties include: a. Assisting with the development of guidance, forms, LRMs, etc. b. Developing and conducting training. c. Developing and Updating Desk Guide Procedures and Worksheets. d. Assigning cases to reviewers. e. Helping with the technical aspects of a case. f. Conducting the discretionary ﬁnal review. g. Sending Preliminary Notiﬁcations. h. Helping management and Compliance, Planning & Classiﬁcation as needed. i. Providing technical assistance to Counsel, as needed. j. Issuing Opinion Letters. k. Verifying User Fees deposited appropriately. l. Determining Grossly Deﬁcient Plans and Innovative Plan Designs. m. Overseeing Pre-approved Plans Correspondence. (

) The Coordinators provide aid to multiple business units to help update and publish guidance, forms, etc. for each pre-approved RAC. Some of the tance that they provide include helping: a. The technical advisor and Counsel to publish the Cumulative List and other guidance relating to the opening and closing of each RAC. b. To update the Form

series by using the Publishing Services Request application. c. EP Technical update the applicable LRM. d. The Office of Taxpayer Correspondence and Counsel approve the content of the Opinion Letter. e. IT programmers to ensure that TRAC is updated for each RAC. f. Write newsletters, hold Provider conference calls, and update the IRS.gov site to keep public informed of changes to the program. (
) The Pre-Approved Plans submitted for each cycle must satisfy the List of Qualiﬁcation Changes for that particular cycle. (

) To ensure a quality and consistent review, the reviewers receive training each new cycle. The training enables the reviewers to understand: a. What’s expected of them. b. The statutory and regulatory changes the Pre-Approved Plans must satisfy. (
) During training, reviewers also receive plan document review tools the nators developed.

) Some Pre-Approved Plan applications may have situations that require tional attention: a. Withdrawal of a Pre-Approved Plan application. b. Assumption of sponsorship. c. Name and/or address changes. d. A grossly deﬁcient plan or an innovative plan design. (
) If a specialist has any additional questions or concerns, they should contact the Coordinators for applicable procedures. (

) A Provider or Mass Submitter may wish to withdraw his/her Pre-Approved application. When they notify you that they want to withdraw, specialists should: a. Notify the Pre-Approved Plans Coordinators immediately. b. Inform the Provider/Mass Submitter that the IRS must receive an letter of withdrawal. c. Inform the Provider/Mass Submitter that the user fee is unless the review has not been started or one of the exceptions in (
) below is met. (
) Upon receipt of the official letter of withdrawal, the Coordinators consider case withdrawn and issue a letter to the Provider/Mass Submitter the withdrawal. (

) If the withdrawal is of a submission of a/an: a. Identical Adopter of a Mass Submitter plan, the IRS refunds the user if the request is made before IRS issues the Opinion Letter. b. Minor Modiﬁcation of a Mass Submitter plan, the IRS refunds the user fee unless the review has started. (
) If an Identical Adopter of a Mass Submitter requests a switch of its to another Mass Submitter, no additional user fee is due if the request is before IRS issues the Opinion Letter. (

) The clerk updates the TRAC status code to show that the case was and completes the explanation ﬁeld on the plan screen to indicate whether refund was set up on a particular date or that no refund applies. (

) In some instances, another entity may assume sponsorship of an existing Approved Plan. If requested, the IRS reissues an Opinion Letter to the new entity if the following requirements are met: a. No additional amendments are made to the plan document. b. The assumption of sponsorship is documented by a change of EIN. c. The new sponsor pays the required fee. See Rev. Proc.
annually). d. The new entity submits any other documentation of the assumption of sponsorship as the IRS requests. (
) The reissued Opinion Letter is dated based on either: a. The postmark date when the new sponsor pays with a certiﬁed or cashier’s check.

) The clerk updates TRAC accordingly and issues the new Opinion Letter the new sponsor’s information. (

) If a Provider or Mass Submitter requests an updated Opinion Letter for: a. Only an address change, they must include a cover letter indicating Address change. No user fee is required. b. A name change, they must include a cover letter and an updated tion. No user fee is required. (
) The clerk updates TRAC accordingly and issues a new Opinion Letter updated information. (
) The IRS won’t rule on grossly deﬁcient plans and innovative plan designs. (

) A grossly deﬁcient Pre-Approved Plan is a plan that is either: Plans Plan a. Substantially out of compliance with the applicable Cumulative List other qualiﬁcation requirements. b. So deﬁcient that the IRS can’t review it in a reasonable amount of (
) If you ﬁnd a grossly deﬁcient plan, stop reviewing it and explain in an the Coordinators: a. Why the plan is considered grossly deﬁcient. b. Any qualiﬁcation issues you discovered. (

) The Pre-Approved Plans Program is meant for traditional plan designs; therefore, innovative plan designs aren’t accepted in the program. If you encounter something in a Pre-Approved Plan that you don’t recognize or which you can’t ﬁnd clear supportive IRS guidance (excluding private rulings), stop your review and contact the Pre-Approved Plans immediately. (

) When a specialist informs the Pre-Approved Coordinators that they have grossly deﬁcient or innovative plan design, the Coordinators: a. Review the document b. If the Coordinators agree with the specialist, they return the plan to Provider and give them

days to resubmit a substantially document. The Coordinators closely analyze any resubmission for pliance before reassigning it for review. c. If the Coordinators do not agree that the plan is grossly deﬁcient or contains an innovative plan design, they return the case to the to continue their review.
